author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Timeline of new NYPD Commissioner Bratton
text:
Todd Maisel/New York Daily News Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio introduced former NYPD Commissioner Bill Bratton (pictured) to return to the job under his administration. The Life and Times of Incoming NYPD Commissioner William Bratton
— Born Oct. 6, 1947
— 1965: Graduates from Boston Technical High School.
— 1970: Following a tour in Vietnam with the U.S. Army, Bratton begins his career as a police officer with the Boston Police Department. He rises through the ranks to head the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority Police in 1983 and later becomes the youngest superintendent of the Massachusetts Metropolitan District Commission Police.
— 1975: Graduates from University of Massachusetts, Boston, with a B.A. in public service and administration. Bratton goes on to become a research fellow at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
— 1990: Bratton becomes chief of the now-defunct New York City Transit Police Department. It is his first time serving in New York.
— 1992: Bratton leaves New York to head the Boston Police Department.
- 1994: Bratton is appointed by then-Mayor Rudy Giuliani to serve as the 38th commissioner of the NYPD. Felony crime falls 39% during Bratton's tenure. His success is largely attributed to the "broken windows" theory, which holds that cracking down on petty crimes prevents more serious offenses. He also pioneers the use of CompStat, the crime tracking system still used by the NYPD today.
— 1996: After repeated clashes with Mayor Giuliani, Bratton resigns from his post. During his time in office, Bratton was investigated for accepting lavish vacations and was criticized by Giuliani over a lucrative book contract. The mayor was reportedly jealous of a Time magazine cover story on Bratton that credited the commissioner with reducing crime in the city. Bratton quit on March 26, 1996, then took a job in the private sector until he was tapped by the Los Angeles mayor to head to LAPD.
— October 2002: Appointed Chief of the Los Angeles Police Department. There, Bratton expands the use of the controversial crime-fighting tactic known as stop-and-frisk. In 2008, 30% of the stops resulted in an arrest, compared with current NYPD commissioner Ray Kelly's record of 6%. Crime falls to historically low levels during Bratton's tenure in L.A.
— July 2009: Bratton leaves the LAPD to work in private consulting. His most recent position was with the law enforcement network start-up company, Bratton Technologies.
— 2011: Bratton discusses with then-British Prime Minister David Cameron the prospect of running London's Metropolitan Police Service. The move is blocked because Bratton is not a British citizen.
— Dec. 5, 2013: Bratton is once again named commissioner of the New York Police Department, this time appointed by Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio.
